DataElement.preferredName: Infusion Procedure Catheter Neoplasm Insertion Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to identify the location of an infusion catheter in reference to a tumor site. [Manually-curated]

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream. Also called intravenous infusion._(KATH-i-ter) A flexible tube used to deliver fluids into or withdraw fluids from the body.__An abnormal tissue growth resulted from uncontrolled cell proliferation._The act of putting one thing into another.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream. Also called intravenous infusion.:(KATH-i-ter) A flexible tube used to deliver fluids into or withdraw fluids from the body.

Concepts.definition: Any form of treatment that is introduced into the body via a blood vessel, a muscle, or the spinal cord.
(KATH-i-ter) A flexible tube used to deliver fluids into or withdraw fluids from the body.

Property.preferredDefinition: (NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.:The act of putting one thing into another.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
The act of putting one thing into another.
